title: 1342-C
statement: C. Yet Another Counting Problemtime limit per test3.5 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given two integers $$$a$$$ and $$$b$$$, and $$$q$$$ queries. The $$$i$$$-th query consists of two numbers $$$l_i$$$ and $$$r_i$$$, and the answer to it is the number of integers $$$x$$$ such that $$$l_i \\le x \\le r_i$$$, and $$$((x \\bmod a) \\bmod b) \\ne ((x \\bmod b) \\bmod a)$$$. Calculate the answer for each query.Recall that $$$y \\bmod z$$$ is the remainder of the division of $$$y$$$ by $$$z$$$. For example, $$$5 \\bmod 3 = 2$$$, $$$7 \\bmod 8 = 7$$$, $$$9 \\bmod 4 = 1$$$, $$$9 \\bmod 9 = 0$$$.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 100$$$) — the number of test cases. Then the test cases follow.The first line of each test case contains three integers $$$a$$$, $$$b$$$ and $$$q$$$ ($$$1 \\le a, b \\le 200$$$; $$$1 \\le q \\le 500$$$).Then $$$q$$$ lines follow, each containing two integers $$$l_i$$$ and $$$r_i$$$ ($$$1 \\le l_i \\le r_i \\le 10^{18}$$$) for the corresponding query.OutputFor each test case, print $$$q$$$ integers — the answers to the queries of this test case in the order they appear.ExampleInput2 4 6 5 1 1 1 3 1 5 1 7 1 9 7 10 2 7 8 100 200Output0 0 0 2 4  0 91

processed.result:
You are given two integers $a$ and $b$, and $q$ queries. Each query consists of two numbers $l_i$ and $r_i$. For each query, find the number of integers $x$ such that $l_i \le x \le r_i$ and  $((x \bmod a) \bmod b) \neq ((x \bmod b) \bmod a)$. 

Here, $y \bmod z$ represents the remainder when $y$ is divided by $z$. 


For example, $5 \bmod 3 = 2$, $7 \bmod 8 = 7$, $9 \bmod 4 = 1$, and $9 \bmod 9 = 0$.

You are given two numbers,  'a' and 'b'. You will be asked multiple times to find the number of integers within a given range (l to r) that do not satisfy a specific condition. The condition is that the remainder when the integer is divided by 'a' and then divided by 'b' must be different from the remainder when the integer is divided by 'b' and then divided by 'a'.
